Toward a validation of cyber-interventions for stress disorders based on stress inoculation training: a systematic review
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • SI: Cyberinterventions
  • Published: 26 October 2013

Toward a validation of cyber-interventions for stress disorders based on stress inoculation training: a systematic review

  • Silvia Serino1,
  • Stefano Triberti2,
  • Daniela Villani2,
  • Pietro Cipresso1,
  • Andrea Gaggioli1,2 &
  • Giuseppe Riva1,2 

Virtual Reality volume 18, pages73–87(2014)Cite this article

  • 1446 Accesses

  • 40 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

New advanced technologies have recently emerged as a potentially effective way for delivering stress management techniques. Specifically, the stress inoculation training (SIT) represents a validated approach to manage stress in several settings, and research is growing related to this clinical protocol combined with advanced technologies. This review aims to outline the state of the art of cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology (cyber-SIT). In the current review, we deeply analyzed and discussed three aspects of the selected studies: (1) the type of technological devices used for delivering cyber-SIT; (2) the sampling strategies; (3) and the stress-related measures for assessing the effectiveness of cyber-SIT. The results of this systematic review suggest the potential efficacy of cyber-SIT for managing psychological stress in several settings. Considering cyber-SIT for psychological stress, controlled trials testing a greater number of participants are needed. Other future challenges include adopting better inclusion/exclusion criteria, standardized outcome measures, and different conditions for comparing the effect and/or the integration of different technological devices. In conclusion, as the cyber-SIT may play an important role in the future clinical psychology, it is crucial to enhance the validation of this approach from a methodological point of view.

Background

In the recent decades, the use of new technologies and digital environments in the context of psychological interventions has considerably increased. In the early years of the Noughties, technology-based interventions were already identified as one of the key elements for the future clinical psychology (Hedges 2002). Advanced technologies are currently integrated in clinical and research settings for supporting psychological treatments and improving well-being (Riva et al. 2012a; Botella et al. 2012). According to Botella and colleagues (2012), the potentiality of technologies for psychological interventions has been demonstrated in the following technological domains: computer-assisted therapy (e.g., Carr et al. 1988; Proudfoot et al. 2004; Marks et al. 2004), virtual reality applications (e.g., Glantz and Rizzo 2003; Riva 2005b, 2009, Riva et al. 2009), and the Internet and its evolution—Web 2.0 (e.g., Andersson 2009; Gorini et al. 2008). Furthermore, thanks to the recent technical development and social diffusion of mobile devices, psychological interventions could be also delivered in daily situations (e.g., Phillips et al. 2010; Kay 2011; Free et al. 2013).

Advanced technologies have recently emerged as a potentially effective way for delivering psychological interventions and, among them, stress management protocols. An increasing amount of evidence showed the efficacy and usefulness of technology to support different types of stress management interventions, comprising relaxation techniques, promotion of an healthy lifestyle, and cognitive-behavioral therapies (Repetto et al. 2009, 2013; Free et al. 2013; Villani and Riva 2012; Goncalves et al. 2012; Meyerbroker and Emmelkamp 2010; Preziosa et al. 2009; Powers and Emmelkamp 2008; Gorini and Riva 2008).

Within the cognitive-behavioral therapies for stress management used in settings that were not mediated, the stress inoculation training (SIT; Meichenbaum 1977, 1985) represents a validated short, semistructured, and active approach to manage psychological stress (for a review, see Stetz et al. 2007b). SIT is a type of training conceived to prepare individuals for stressful events by helping them in diminishing the potential for a negative cognitive, psychological, and behavioral reaction. In fact, the psychological stress could be conceived as a condition that severely disrupts the balance between the individual’s perception of his/her skills and the perception of difficulty of the environmental requirements. In general terms, when a stimulus challenges the individual with a potential threat, a complex physiological, psychological, and behavioral response is induced in order to mobilize several resources to effectively adapt to it. According to Cohen and colleagues (2007), psychological stress occurs when individuals perceive that these potential threats exceed his/her adaptive capacity. There is no “best” stress response: An optimal adaptation to environmental demands requires the ability to flexibly use our coping strategies depending on the particular context and the specific stressors. In order to effectively manage stress, it is crucial to change the way we see the events and how to use our coping skills. According to these premises, SIT is generally implemented through gradual and repeated exposure to the elements previously identified as stressors. The clinical rationale behind this approach is to “inoculate” the stressor in person’s experience, in combination with the acquisition of effective coping skills, so that he/she could be prepared when he/she will encounter similar situations in daily life. SIT has been validated in several contexts, such as in the clinical setting, to help patients in facing particularly strenuous conditions (Foley et al. 1987; Moore and Altmaier 1981; Ross and Berger 1996), in the occupational environment, to support employees in effectively managing stressful situations (Cecil and Forman 1990; von Baeyer and Krause 1983) and in the sport, and to prepare athletes in managing anxiety and improving performance (Mace and Carroll 1986; Saunders et al. 1996).

The general objectives of SIT are threefold: (a) to change the maladaptive stress response of the individual, thanks to the acquisition of active coping strategies; (b) to develop an activity of self-regulation; and (c) to explore and modify dysfunctional cognitive appraisal related to stressful events. According to these goals, the SIT protocol includes three phases. The first phase, named conceptualization, aims at making individual aware of the transactional nature of psychological stress (Lazarus and Folkman 1987) by giving general information about the main stress’ effects and symptoms that could appear in different stressful situations. The second phase, named skill acquisition and rehearsal, aims at teaching individual to manage emotions and maladaptive behaviors as well as learn new active coping skills. The strategies include problems focused coping techniques (problem-solving training, time management training, and communication abilities training) and emotions focused coping techniques (relaxation techniques, change of perspective, and effective emotional expression). The last phase, named application and follow-through, aims at increasing self-efficacy (Bandura 1998) by helping individual to use the acquired coping skills in real contexts. Typical techniques used in this phase are the imaginative rehearsal (individual has to image stressful scenarios and to think about coping strategies), the behavioral rehearsal (role-playing), and the graded in vivo exposure.

The main objectives and the three stages of SIT have been recently implemented in cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology (cyber-SIT), which utilize advanced technologies to create simulations to teach individual how effectively cope with psychological stress (Wiederhold and Wiederhold 2006, 2008; Stetz et al. 2007b). Specifically, we consider that the use of advanced technology may efficiently support all the three phases of SIT. As far as the conceptualization phase, the interactive virtual worlds can use motivation to teach the users about the transactional nature of stress, and its main causes and effects (Riva et al. 2012b). Furthermore, the efficacy of multimedia learning is widely known, assuming that learner’s cognitive load is controlled (Mayer and Moreno 2003): New communication technologies can provide multimedia presentations where information is enriched and distributed through images, animations, sound, voice, and written text. A learner-centered approach in designing multimedia (Mayer 2009) could enhance not only the reception of instructional material, but also a profound understanding of it: Learners of multimedia presentation perform better in transfer tests or rather are much able to utilize learned abilities in natural contexts (Mayer and Wittrock 2006; Bruning et al. 2004).

With respect to the skill acquisition and rehearsal phase, advanced technologies can help individuals in acquiring effective coping skills, such as relaxation strategies (Stetz et al. 2011; Manzoni et al. 2009; Villani and Riva 2012). In particular, technologies such as virtual reality could guarantee participants meaningful experience in interactive environments: Bandura (2004) suggests that interactive features are the greatest strength of new media. Computer-based feedback can be specified to accommodate the individual’s motivations, current self-efficacy levels, unique obstacles and setbacks, and progress toward specific goals. Participants could experience exercise behavior, with technology administering positive reinforcement of healthy conducts, to the aim of empowering their coping strategies and problem comprehension (Fox and Bailenson 2009; Bordnick et al. 2011).

Finally, as far as the application and follow-through phase, it is known that the main uses of digital environments are related to patients’ exposure to stressful stimuli, as in the treatment of phobias or posttraumatic stress disorder: Researches demonstrated that the exposure to multimedia/virtual contents has therapeutic benefits for participants, often equal to those of the in vivo exposure (Emmelkamp et al. 2001, 2002) and/or superior to other methods such as guided imagery (Rothbaum et al. 1999; Vincelli 1999; Riva 2005a; North et al. 1997) and no treatment (Wiederhold and Wiederhold 2003; Rothbaum et al. 1995). Within a cyber-SIT, this could be particularly useful in the last phase by creating controlled, graded, and safe simulations of stressful scenarios to allow participant to use the acquired coping skills.

Beyond the exposure, currently there are other techniques used to consolidate the acquired coping skills, such as self-attribution procedures, relapse prevention procedures, and help others with similar problems and booster sessions (Meichenbaum 1977, 1985). In particular, throughout the training process, especially at the end of the treatment, the therapist should guarantee that the client “takes credit” for any significant improvement. This process is known as “self-attribution,” and it usually occurs by asking a client with a series of questions that pull for self-attribution, such as “Have you handled the situation now compared with how you handled in the past?” Another important procedure is that of relapse prevention, which is aimed at discussing with client what he/she had learned in order to identify future high-risk situations and effective ways of coping with them. These techniques could also be inserted in a cyber-SIT by using interactive simulations on mobile phones where the client has the chance to immediately put into practice the acquired skills and receives meaningful feedback. Mobile devices are becoming more and more useful also in healthcare services (Free et al. 2013). Specifically, thanks to recent development and diffusion of mobile platforms, stress management protocols could be integrated beyond the traditional clinical setting to deliver real-time support during daily life activities. For instance, it is possible to reexperience the same virtual situation to facilitate the process of self-attribution or create an interactive digital environment where client can choose different course of actions to enhance the ability to recognize warning signs.

According to these premises, as the cyber-SIT may play an important role in the future clinical psychology, it is important that it is extensively defined in its both clinical and methodological elements. Specifically, for an appropriate development of validated protocols of cyber-SIT, it is important to have a deeper comprehension of the opportunities and limitations it will provide according to different advanced technologies. This will allow us to understand what is the specific role of different technologies (e.g., virtual reality—VR—or mobile phone) in facilitating the process of therapeutic change.

In the current review, we aimed to outline the state of the art of cyber-SIT in order to provide guidelines to enhance the validation of this promising cyber-intervention.

Methods

We followed the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines (Moher et al. 2009).

Search strategy

To achieve this, a computer-based search in several databases was performed for relevant publications. Databases used for the search were the following: PsycINFO, Social Sciences Citation Index (Web of Knowledge), PubMed/MEDLINE, and Web of Science (Web of Knowledge).

The search string was the following: “stress disorders” AND (“technology” OR “technologies” OR “mobile” OR “virtual reality” OR “cyber” OR “multimedia” OR “audio”).

The articles were individually scanned to elaborate whether they fulfill the following inclusion criteria: (a) research article; (b) using stress inoculation training protocol; (c) providing information about the used sample; and (d) providing information about stress-related measures. These inclusion criteria were used for several reasons. This search strategy allowed us to include all the existent research studies using cyber-SIT in all its clinical elements and phases. As noted above, information about the sample and stress-related measures are a prerequisite for defining cyber-SIT and to compare different studies. Furthermore, this information will be used to discuss guidelines to develop future cyber-interventions for stress disorders based on SIT methodology.

Systematic review flow

The flow chart of the systematic review is shown in Fig. 1. Our initial search yielded 1,559 non-duplicate citations screened including PsycINFO, Social Sciences Citation Index (Web of Knowledge), PubMed, MEDLINE, and Web of Science (Web of Knowledge: WoK): More details are available in Table 1. After the application of the inclusion criteria, papers have been reduced to 224 articles. A deeper investigation of the full papers showed exclusion of 215 articles. During the data extraction procedure, two additional full papers were excluded. In the end, only seven studies met full criteria and were included in this review (Table 1). A flow diagram showing the procedure is detailed in Fig. 1.

More, since some article may use SIT without including “stress disorder” in the abstract or keywords, we also searched in the above databases “stress inoculation training.” Two hundred and thirty-five articles have arisen from search, where 159 were excluded after title/abstract screen. The remaining 76 articles have been fully screened to search whether any technology was used in the protocol. Only one new article (Timmons et al. 1997) was found. Expert colleagues in the field were contacted for suggestion on further studies not considered in our search. Three new studies arose and have been included in the analyzed studies. To assess a risk of bias, PRISMA recommendations for systematic literature analysis have been strictly followed. Two authors (S.S. and P.C.) independently selected paper abstracts and titles and analyzed the full papers that met the inclusion criteria, resolving disagreements through consensus.

At the very end, ten studies have been included and reported in Table 2.

Results

Despite a broad panorama of studies that use advanced technologies in support of the assessment and management of stress disorders, little has been done to ensure an adequate development of cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology (cyber-SIT). In the current review, we aimed to outline the state of the art of cyber-SIT in order to provide guidelines to ensure an adequate development of future studies that enhance the validation of this promising cyber-intervention. To this aim, three aspects of the selected studies will be fully reviewed and discussed: (1) the type of technological devices used for delivering cyber-SIT; (2) the sampling strategies; (3) and the stress-related measures for assessing the effectiveness of cyber-SIT.

The selected studies will be analyzed to assess the quality of the methodology and to collect important indications for future studies. A synthesis of results has been reported in Table 3.

Cyber-SIT: methods and technology

In order to ensure an adequate development of cyber-SIT, it is crucial to have a deep comprehension of the opportunities and limitations that it will provide according to different advanced technologies (e.g., virtual reality and mobile phone) and their specific role in improving the process of therapeutic change.

Timmons and colleagues offered the first example of cyber-SIT (Timmons et al. 1997). They developed and tested a computer-assisted guidance program that consisted of a computer-assisted instruction (CAI) for delivering anger-management treatment based on SIT methodology (Timmons et al. 1997). The study showed the effectiveness of computer guidance programs for treating individuals with maladaptive anger, as compared to group treatment and waitlist controls. As authors noted, CAI systems were particularly useful to deliver skills training, since they are interactive computer programs that use effective tutorials to set specific learning objectives, provide information and skills, evaluate performance, and present useful feedback to the learner. CAI can also provide simulations that allow individuals to apply what they learned to real-life situations.

It is important to note that this is the only selected study focusing on the treatment of anger-related disorders. More recent studies have shown the efficacy of VR-based treatment for treating anger disorders (Brinkman et al. 2011; Miyahira et al. 2010). These studies suggest the potentiality of VR in the treatment of anger by exposing participants to realistic virtual anger-provoking environments, such as aggressive dialogues.

New advanced technologies have indeed expanded these preliminary clinical advantages for delivering cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology.

Stetz et al. proposed a VR-SIT (2007a). Coping skills, such as combat breathing, have first been learned in a safe environment. After this coping skill was taught, the individual was asked to perform acquired skill in a virtual environment simulating Iraqi or Afghan combat scenarios. Specifically, participants in cyber-SIT group (VR game play session + coping training) were required to navigate through a stressful, but controlled, simulated combat environment, while performing tasks, such as putting a tourniquet on a casualty or administering pain medication. Preliminary findings suggest that soldiers, who learned coping techniques during the VR training, exhibited lower levels of stress than the control group.

Four selected studies developed and tested another interesting VR-SIT according to the Virtual Reality Medical Center (San Diego, USA) methodology (Ilnicki et al. 2012; Kosinska et al. 2012; Zbyszeswki et al. 2012; Maciolek et al. 2012). Participants were invited to listen 90-min lecture on the transactional nature of psychological stress. Then, participants in the experimental group participated actively in the training and could interact in a virtual environment simulating a military mission. The training consisted of ten sessions and started with the creation of a psychophysiological profile. Then, the training included VR exposure to increasingly stressful combat stimuli, and participants learned how to reduce their arousal through breathing training and arousal reduction training with physiological feedback.

In these four selected studies, VR has been used to deliver graded exposure. Exposure methods comprise confrontation with frightening, but realistically safe, stimuli that continues until stress response is reduced. Users are immersed in a virtual environment (VE) that continuously updates the user’s head and/or body motion. When users are immersed in a VE, they can be systematically and safely exposed to specific feared stimuli within a contextually relevant environment. The flexibility of VE allows the therapist to tailor sessions to meet the needs of each client, offering the following clinical advantages: interactivity, flexibility, controllability, confidentiality, safety, time-saving, cost-saving, and repeatability (Gorini and Riva 2008). Another possibility for using VR-SIT is non-immersive virtual reality systems. For example, Hourani and colleagues (Hourani et al. 2011) compared two groups of marine soldiers, analyzing their psychophysiological response (heart rate variability) and interaction measures (reaction time) in a “multimedia stress environment.” The “multimedia stress environment” consisted in Iraqi simulated scenario, and it is aimed at inducing psychophysiological arousal during a simulated training mission to assess and train participants’ abilities in applying coping skills. They include biofeedback-assisted breathing retraining, as well as attentional control training. In phase A of the study, while the control group was trained with educational slides material, the experimental group was exposed to the multimedia stress non-immersive virtual environment (participants watched it on a screen, in little groups, as if they were moving in the simulated Iraqi village on a military vehicle). In phase B of the training, both the groups were exposed to a live combat training scenario. Results showed the effectiveness of the “multimedia stress environment” in improving relaxation, as measured by heart rate variability, for previously deployed marines, particularly those with more PTSD symptoms.

Other selected studies explore the potentiality of different technological devices for delivering cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology: the mobile phones. Villani and colleagues compared a cyber-SIT delivered through mobile phones with a control group (neutral video through mobile phones) in a sample of 30 female oncology nurses (Villani et al. 2013). Results showed psychological improvement of the experimental group in terms of anxiety state, anxiety trait reduction, and coping skills acquisition. Within the same theoretical account, Riva and colleagues (Riva et al. 2007) found better efficacy of mobile narratives experienced on UMTS phones in reducing the level of examination stress and in helping the student to relax. The key feature of these cyber-interventions based on the SIT methodology was represented by the use of mobile tools to increase patients’ involvement and control in their treatment. Mobile phone can respond to various clinical needs (Preziosa et al. 2009), and according to Villani et al., the advantages of using a mobile approach to deliver SIT could be an incremental acquisition of coping skills in an autonomous way (Storr 1990), a ubiquitous and effective support in facing daily stressful situations, an enhancement of people’s acceptance (Cleland et al. 2007), and the possibility of living graded exposure experiences while overcoming the difficulties related to the application of coping techniques within a clinical setting. Finally, Grassi et al. (2011) proposed another interesting example. They developed and tested a new cyber-SIT protocol aimed at reducing examination anxiety by combining different media: UMTS mobile phone, DVD, Mp3 Player, and Audio CD. Results suggest that the audio/video format is more effective than the audio-only format in the emotion induction procedure.

Cyber-SIT: sampling strategies

According to the specific aims of the applications of cyber-SIT, it emerges that there are different sampling strategies. Specifically, it is possible to identify three sampling strategies within cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology: (1) methods aimed at selecting non-clinical samples; (2) methods aimed at selecting samples with stress-related symptoms; (3) and methods aimed at selecting samples according to a specific context.

Six selected studies tested the efficacy of cyber-SIT to improve soldiers’ performance and increase their stress resilience and prevent chronic psychological disorders (e.g., posttraumatic stress disorder) (Stetz et al. 2007a; Ilnicki et al. 2012; Hourani et al. 2011; Kosinska et al. 2012; Maciolek et al. 2012; Zbyszeswki et al. 2012). In these research studies, a deep screening procedure has been carried out. Specifically, since the incidence of PTSD among soldiers is widely acknowledged (Gates et al. 2012; Becher 2011), it is crucial to assess the presence of such disorders.

To select a non-clinical sample, Stetz et al. (2007a), Ilnicki et al. (2012), Maciolek et al. (2012), Kosinska et al. (2012), and Zbyszeswki et al. (2012) used the “PTSD Checklist-Military Version” (Weathers et al. 1991). To establish baseline information on participant’s mental health status, Hourani et al. (2011), instead, used the “PTSD Checklist-Civilian Version” (Weathers et al. 1994), an instrument useful to identify potential PTSD symptoms prior to military service.

Two selected studies evaluated the effectiveness of cyber-SIT in reducing maladaptive cognitive and emotional responses (Timmons et al. 1997; Villani et al. 2013). Starting from the idea that participants may feel more engaged if they consider the experience to be crucial for their needs and goals (Scherer 2001), which is also true for mediated experiences as well (Villani et al. 2007; Riva and Mantovani 2012), Villani et al. developed and tested a cyber-SIT (2013) on oncology nurses with a cutoff level of psychology stress corresponding to the higher quartile (Italian normative data), measured using the Mesure du Stress Psychologique (MSP) Questionnaire (Di Nuovo et al. 2000; Tessier et al. 1990). Timmons et al. (1997) conducted semistructured interviews to screen for the presence of anger problems, availability of treatment, and reading level.

Finally, two selected studies tested the efficacy of cyber-SIT in reducing examination anxiety and acquiring coping abilities (specifically, relaxation strategies) in university students (Riva et al. 2007; Grassi et al. 2011). In these studies, there was no specific screening procedure: University students who were going to perform an examination within a week were included.

Cyber-SIT: stress-related measures

There are several ways to assess the efficacy of a stress management intervention. In general terms, it is possible to use three different evaluation strategies: (1) a direct assessment of individual’s perceived subjective stress; (2) an indirect assessment of factors that mediate the stress response, such as anger, anxiety, and coping abilities; and (3) a psychophysiological assessment of stress indexes, such as breathing rate, heart rate, heart rate variability, skin conductance, and skin temperature. The interpretation of a situation as being stressful activates the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenocortical axis (HPA) and finally to the secretion of cortisol and catecholamines. These end products of HPA activation are also easily measurable in individuals. Specifically, salivary cortisol has become one of the most innocuous ways to measure psychophysiological reactions to stress (Kirschbaum and Hellhammer 1994). These different stress-related measures are considered to assess the efficacy of cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology.

Concerning the direct assessment of psychological stress, only one selected study used a self-report focused on individual’s perceived subjective stress to assess the effectiveness of the intervention (Kosinska et al. 2012). Kosinska and colleagues, in fact, used the Subjective Units of Distress Scale (SUDS) for assessing the subjective stress level (from 0 to 100) after each session.

To assess the effectiveness of cyber-SIT, most of the selected studies used an indirect measure of psychological stress or a combination with a psychophysiological assessment of stress indexes.

As in traditional SIT, the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI, (Spielberger et al. 1970) is one of the mostly used instrument to measure the anxiety-related changes in cyber-SIT (Ilnicki et al. 2012; Maciolek et al. 2012; Riva et al. 2007; Grassi et al. 2011; Zbyszeswki et al. 2012). STAI is a self-report instrument widely used in anxiety disorders research, and it evaluates both state (or current) and trait (or characteristic or chronic) anxiety. Timmons et al. (1997), instead, used the State-Trait Anger Expression Inventory (Spielberger 1991). STAXI is a self-report that assesses intensity of angry feelings and the frequency that anger was experienced, expressed, suppressed, or controlled.

To assess the emotional and affective changes, two selected studies (Riva et al. 2007; Grassi et al. 2011) used the VAS to measure the relaxation level achieved after each session (Gross and Levenson 1995). Specifically, Riva and his team also introduced the well-known “PANAS: Positive and Negative Affect Schedule” (Watson et al. 1988). This self-report was administered at the beginning of the treatment, and before and after the university examination.

To measure subjective trait characteristics that affect changes in response to stressful situations, Stetz et al. (2007a) used the “Multiple Affect Adjective Check List-Revised” (Zuckerman and Lubin 1965), which measures anxiety, depression, and hostility. Two selected studies introduced a measure of coping abilities (Ilnicki et al. 2012; Villani et al. 2013). Ilnicki et al. (2012) and Zbyszeswki et al. (2012) administered an adapted version of the Coping Inventory in Stressful Situations (CISS) questionnaire (Strelau et al. 2005) to determine behavior patterns of an individual in stressful situations. Villani et al. (2013) also introduced an Italian translation of four items from the Brief Coping Orientation to Problems Experienced (COPE) questionnaires (Carver 1997) for assessing coping skills in terms of active coping and denial.

To evaluate the effectiveness of cyber-SIT in terms of participants’ mental health status, prior deployment experience, and combat experience, Hourani and colleagues developed a 20-predeployment questionnaire, including the “PTSD Checklist-Civilian Version” (Weathers et al. 1994), Patient Health Questionnaire-Anxiety Subscale (Kroenke et al. 2002), the Center for Epidemiological Studies-Depression Scale (Tuunainen et al. 2001), Two-Item Conjoint Screening (Brown et al. 2001), and the Combat Exposure Scale (Keane et al. 1989).

It is interesting to note that in some selected studies, personality traits’ measures are also considered (Ilnicki et al. 2012; Kosinska et al. 2012; Maciolek et al. 2012; Zbyszeswki et al. 2012). For instance, Zbyszeswki et al. (2012) used an adapted version of Revised NEO Personality Inventory (NEO PI-R) (Siuta 2006), and The Formal Characteristics of Behaviour-Temperament Inventory (FCB-TI) (Zawadzki and Strelau 2010) to investigate different responses of participants to cyber-SIT effects in relation to individual differences. Specifically, they found a correlation between a more harmonized personality structure and the results of SIT training.

As regards the psychophysiological assessment of stress, four selected studies introduced also several physiological indexes of stress (Timmons et al. 1997; Stetz et al. 2007a; Hourani et al. 2011; Kosinska et al. 2012). Specifically, cardiovascular and respiratory activities are monitored to evaluate both voluntary and autonomic effect of respiration on heart rate, analyzing measures extracted from electrocardiogram, respiration (from chest strip sensor), and their interaction.

Timmons and colleagues used blood pressure as a physiological measure of anger, since elevations in systolic and diastolic blood pressure have widely been found to correlate positively with anger (Hokanson et al. 1968, 1971; Schum et al. 2003).

Stetz et al. (2007a) monitored objective physiological stress indexes from participants using a “PhysioLab.” The PhysioLab is a device that captures (among other parameters) peripheral body temperature, breathing rate, and pulse rate.

One of the mostly used measures in stress psychophysiological studies is heart rate variability (HRV). In particular, spectral method is used to compute indexes to evaluate the autonomic nervous system response to provocative stimuli (Ahuja and Carley 1998; Barbieri et al. 2002; Kramer 1999; Lewicki et al. 2006; Malik et al. 1996). Kosinska et al. (2012) used HRV as an indicator of relaxation/arousal. In their pilot study, Hourani et al. (2011) considered HRV as index of stress/relaxation in soldiers who were exposed to a stressful virtual environment. Focusing the study on performance effectiveness, reaction times to interactive elements in the virtual environment were considered too. After the cyber-SIT, participants in the experimental group increased their hit rate (namely a correct button-press response to target object in the virtual scenario) significantly to 91 %, while control group’s participants decreased significantly to 85 %. These data suggest the efficacy of cyber-SIT in improving attentional abilities as effective coping skills.

Finally, only one selected study used a salivary amylase test as a measure of biochemical stress (Stetz et al. 2007a). Preliminary results showed that the recorded time of salivary amylase transformation increases with the inoculations participants experience. This evidence suggests the efficacy of these tools in inducing a level of stress high enough to potentially produce an “inoculation” effect. With respect to the assessment of autonomic response to stress exposure, as previously explained, HRV may be a useful psychophysiological marker also in this context. It could be interesting to investigate whether, under inoculation experience, there is a decrease in HRV.

Conclusion

Psychological stress is a common and potentially severe condition seriously associated not only with several diseases (Cohen et al. 2007), such as other mental health disorders, cardiovascular disease, and more rapid clinical progression in HIV infection (Rozanski et al. 1999; Leserman et al. 2002; Antoni et al. 2006), but also with elevated premature mortality (for a recent review, see Russ et al. 2012).

To manage stress, there is a growing need to find innovative and effective interventions in healthcare services. As fully explained earlier, an increasing number of studies showed how advanced technologies may improve the traditional stress management interventions (Repetto et al. 2013; Free et al. 2013; Villani and Riva 2012; Goncalves et al. 2012; Meyerbroker and Emmelkamp 2010; Preziosa et al. 2009; Powers and Emmelkamp 2008; Gorini and Riva 2008). Here, we specifically focused on cyber-interventions based on SIT methodology, in order to understand their potential for future applications in both clinical and research settings.

The challenge of validation for technology integration in health interventions is related to the use of precise protocols that are comparable through different studies, an aim that is partially achieved in the context of a widely diffuse application as cyber-SIT: Describing the state of the art of this protocol, the present review aims to improve the comparison between different effective attempts that are available in the literature, coming closer to the identification of excellent practices for research and intervention.

According to the results of this systematic review, cyber-SIT appears to be a promising clinical approach, and there are interesting researches that effectively combined traditional SIT clinical protocol within advanced technologies. However, the trade-off between the progress of health technologies on the one hand and the need of rigor and generalizability on the other has still to cope with methodological challenges falling into four areas.

First challenge is the number of studies carried out in this research field. Because it is an emerging field of research, there are still few studies in the literature meeting the requirement of using cyber-SIT in all its clinical elements and phases. As the cyber-SIT may play an important role in the future clinical psychology, it is crucial that future studies will be methodologically stronger to enhance the validation of this approach.

According to the analysis adopted in this review, second is the requirement to identify the most effective technologies for delivering cyber-SIT. In particular, two main groups of technologies emerged in this review, as considered for application in cyber-SIT: virtual-interactive environments and mobile technologies. Certainly, they may offer different challenges and opportunities to cyber-interventions: While virtual environments allow participants to experience meaningful interactions with stressful environments and to learn coping abilities, mobile technologies are suitable for multimedia presentation of contents and are useful to provide assessment of participants in their everyday life.

Within this perspective, an interesting possible future approach is offered by the interreality paradigm, which is based on the following integrated devices/platforms for managing psychological stress (Riva et al. 2010; Gaggioli et al. 2011; Repetto and Riva 2011):

  1. (a)

    3D individual and/or shared virtual reality worlds: They allow a controlled exposure, an objective psychophysiological assessment, and the provision of motivating and engaging feedbacks;

  2. (b)

    Personal digital assistants and/or mobile phones (from the virtual world to the real one): They allow the chance to conduct a real-time psychophysiological assessment and to deliver psychological interventions during daily activities;

  3. (c)

    Personal biomonitoring system (from the real world to the virtual one): It allows a pervasive psychophysiological assessment through wearable biosensors both in clinical and in ecological settings and a decision support system for treatment.

Further studies are needed to develop increasingly sophisticated methods for robust assessments of these rapidly evolving technologies.

The third challenge is related to the sampling strategies. As cyber-SIT may be used in different context, our results suggest the importance of critically choosing the sampling strategies according to the specific aim of the protocol. Participants may feel more engaged if they consider the experience to be crucial for their needs and goals (Scherer 2001), and this is also true for mediated experiences (Villani et al. 2007; Riva and Mantovani 2012). Specifically, as there are differences between chronic stress (such as the PTSD) and acute stress related to a specific situation (such as before an examination), it is important to fully define the inclusion/exclusion criteria. Furthermore, up to now some studies included small samples, while controlled trials testing a greater number of participants are needed.

Fourthly, there is the challenge of the heterogeneity of the measures used for assessing the effectiveness of cyber-SIT. The critical analysis of the selected studies suggests the salience of a multidimensional assessment of stress to test the efficacy of a cyber-SIT, as we can find in traditional interventions, based on a direct assessment of the subjective stress, an indirect assessment of factors that mediate the stress response, or a psychophysiological assessment. However, a common methodological weakness of selected studies was noted, such as the absence of the follow-up to assess the long-term effects of the cyber-SIT.

Psychological interventions should adjust to the changing world and adopt new, innovative tools to better meet clients’ expectations and needs. Technological innovations are driving modern health care at an accelerating pace, and researchers must provide robust, relevant, and accessible assessments in order to make possible this important change. According to Vakili et al. (2012), first of all it is important to follow four guidelines to avoid limiting factors, which were found to constrain the technological developments: culture, namely the social aspect with the parties or stakeholders involved in the development; effectiveness, namely the ability of the system to achieve its goals; engineering, namely the ingenuity required to solve problems, design, or implement; and resource constraints, namely the use of a resource (time, money, information, and expertise). Furthermore, on the basis of the results of our systematic review, the future studies will meet the challenge of the validation of cyber-SIT: (1) by integrating several stress-related measures to verify the efficacy of this promising cyber-intervention at a physiological, psychological, and biochemical level; (2) by integrating different technological devices to fully exploit their potential advantages in different phases of SIT; and (3) by choosing appropriate samples according to the specific aim of the cyber-SIT.
